Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: VeLveT Ice - eVoLution of Fabric and Texture in Ice at WAIS Divide, West Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
1142167/Pettit

This award supports a project to develop a better understanding of the relation between ice microstructure, impurities, and ice flow and their connection to climate history for the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) ice core site. This work builds on several ongoing studies at Siple Dome in West Antarctica and Dome C in East Antarctica. It is well known that the microstructure of ice evolves with depth and time in an ice sheet. This evolution of microstructure depends on the ice flow field, temperature, and impurity content. The ice flow field, in turn, depends on microstructure, leading to feedbacks that create layered variation in microstructure that relates to climate and flow history. The research proposed here focuses on developing a better understanding of: 1) how ice microstructure evolves with time and stress in an ice sheet and how that relates to impurity content, temperature, and strain rate; 2) how variations in ice microstructure and impurity content affect ice flow patterns near ice divides (on both small (1cm to 1m) and large (1m to 100km) scales); and 3) in what ways is the spatial variability of ice microstructure and its effect on ice flow important for interpretation of climate history in the WAIS Divide ice core. The study will integrate existing ice core and borehole data with a detailed study of ice microstructure using Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD) techniques and measurements of borehole deformation through time using Acoustic Televiewers. This will be the first study to combine these two novel techniques for studying the relation between microstructure and deformation and it will build on other data being collected as part of other WAIS Divide borehole logging projects (e.g. sonic velocity, optical dust logging, temperature and other measurements on the ice core including fabric measurements from thin section analyses as well as studies of ice chemistry and stable isotopes. The intellectual merit of the work is that it will improve interpretation of ice core data (especially information on past accumulation) and overall understanding of ice flow. The broader impacts are that the work will ultimately contribute to a better interpretation of ice core records for both paleoclimate studies and for ice flow history, both of which connect to the broader questions of the role of ice in the climate system. The work will also advance the careers of two early-career female scientists, including one with a hearing impairment disability. This project will support a PhD student at the UAF and provide research and field experience for two or three undergraduates at Dartmouth. The PIs plan to include a teacher on their field team and collaborate with UAF's "From STEM to STEAM" toward enhancing the connection between art and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice flow models are used to determine the future effects of climate change on sea levels, the ages of deep ice cores, and the shape and size of paleo ice sheets, among other things. These models rely on us being able to predict the deformation of ice under different stress regimes. Glen originally used measurements of ice flow in ice boreholes and closure of tunnels in glaciers to determine the relationship between the driving stresses and resulting ice flow. The addition of the Arrhenius relationship to this Glen’s Flow Law takes into account the effect of temperature. Despite working well in many situations, Glen’s Flow Law still fails to capture ice flow to the degree needed for many modeling studies.  In particular, measurements of ice deformation in the field and laboratory have highlighted the need to incorporate ice properties, like crystal fabric (a measure of the orientations of ice crystal c-axes within a sample), grain size (often the mean grain size as measured from thin sections of ice), and impurity content (both soluble and insoluble impurities). For example,  an ice crystal has layers like a deck of cards and the pattern of orientation of the layers (fabric) with respect to the stress changes its behavior. Crystal size is thought to also play a role, but disentangling the effect of crystal size and crystal orientation fabric is not easy. Especially when the pattern measurements of each are highly correlated.  . The research conducted with this award aimed to use novel technology to tease apart the crystal size, crystal orientation fabric, and properties such as dust by making high spatial resolution deformation measurements of a 3km deep borehole through the ice.  


Past studies of these effects have been hindered by the incompatible timescales between laboratory and natural environments.  Laboratory studies require modifications in ice properties or stresses to measure deformation in a few years. In natural ice sheets, these studies are hindered by both the slow timescales and a lack of highly detailed ice properties and deformation data.

 

Our study of ice flow within the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide borehole used an acoustic televiewer, which measures both the tilt and closure of a borehole over time. Essentially, we are perturbing the ice sheet by drilling the hole and then watching the ice flow to close the borehole. We are not the first to use this borehole closure approach, but with new technology and a well studied and documented ice core in the right location, we were able to do  a more comprehensive analysis than in previous studies. 


Our results indicate that fabric is the more dominant control on ice flow than the crystal size or impurities. After accounting for temperature, the major discrepancies between expected flow and measured flow (in both tilt and closure - two different styles of deformation) are in sections with strong crystal fabrics. Importantly, we are not just comparing magnitudes of deformation  but the magnitude and style (e.g. shear versus compression); crystal fabric affects both the magnitude and style of the deformation, while crystal size and impurities only affect the magnitude. Impurities and grain size may have small secondary impacts on ice flow, though these properties are highly correlated and their impacts are near the uncertainty limits of our data. 


Moving forward, we hope to continue to use the acoustic televiewer, which has been modified for use at extremely cold temperatures. We successfully collected 288pt caliper readings of the South Pole Ice Core borehole at 1.5cm depth resolution, which will allow us to analyse closure at a much higher level of detail than we were able to at the WAIS Divide borehole. This will allow us to further separate the impacts of fabric, grain size, and impurities on flow while reducing measurement uncertainties as well as uncertainties in the driving stresses.
